Man, I've tested four releases of this title.
- Black.Swan.2010.Blu-ray.RE.x264.720p.DTS.MySilu
- Black.Swan.2010.Blu-ray.RE.x264.1080p.DTS.MySilu
- Black.Swan.2010.BluRay.720p.DTS.x264-CHD
- Black.Swan.2010.BluRay.1080p.DTS.x264-CHD

When I watched the 720p screener of this, I didn't realize how much grain there is in this film. It's quite insane, actually, not just luma noise but lots of chroma noise, too. So much, in fact, that both of the MySilu versions are really way under the required bitrate. They look smudged and full of ugly artifacts. The 720p almost looks like a DVD rip with the 1080p at times looking like a bad 720p rip.

The CHD ones are (obviously, with their immense filesizes) much nicer to look at. Very little artifacts, and the noise is sharp and noisy rather than blurry.

Now the question is whether there's so much noise there that you actually gain enough from a 1080p version to justify its large filesize. It's close to not being so, actually. The grain is just so prominent, that to some extent, what you're actually gaining with the higher resolution isn't so much picture detail as it's prettier noise!

Me, I like noise, so I've gone with the 1080p CHD release. But if you want high detail without blur yet not spend the extra gigs required for that massive 14-gigger, and you're considering the MySilu 1080p one just because it's 1080p, my advice to you is: Don't. Get the CHD 720p instead. It's more detailed than the 1080p MySilu, because that one is just getting terrible smudging effects from the codec not having enough bits to produce much more than blur.

Actually, I'd say the 14GB CHD is pretty much around the sweet spot for 1080p. Much less and quality would start to suffer.

@s0mnambul1st

If the file is over 4gb you have to split it. PS3 doesn't support video files larger. So under the File Splitting drop down, select FAT32 (4GB). If that's not your problem then idk o_O. Lemme know if it was tho.

http://www.blu-ray.com/movies/Black-Swan-Blu-ray/20029/#Review

Professional Review

The PS3 supports files larger than 4GB, you can stream them using a media server or ever host the content and download it to the PS3's hard drive using the media server.  The issue is that the PS3 does not recognize file systems beyond FAT and FAT32, that is where the 4GB file size limit comes into play.  It has absolutely nothing to do with the file system used with the PS3's internal hard drive.

As for the grain, that was intended.  Many directors are either still shooting on film or they digitally insert grain (ala 300).  They do this as it gives the movie a gritty feeling.  The streets of Gotham in The Dark Knight looked great with a thin layer of grain and I couldn't imagine them any other way.  Even The Social Network used grain in many scenes to emphasize the setting (small college dorms, a bar, etc.).

Not every movie is supposed to look pristine and it is exactly what the director's intended, get over it.  But meh, meh, meh, I doesn't wunt teh grane!  Fuck off.  I am tired of hearing people complain about the grain in high def releases when it is mostly intentional and adds so much to the experience.  Black Swan would not look the same without the grain and the characters would all look like plastic dolls.

As for this release, it looks pretty good and will likely hold me over until they release a more comprehensive version of the movie. It is my understanding that there are a handful of special features on the retail Blu-ray release but they are holding back even more content.

@Timdezot If you weren't a complete retard you'd notice that the movie wasn't shot at 16:9. So.. if you wanted a movie 1920 by 1080p, you would need to alter the pixel aspect ratio - which 264x does not support. OR you could change to divX/XviD which are crap at size/quality ratio compared to x264.

So this is in fact full HD. Get your fucking facts right next time you bash a quality torrent.
